DOCNAME: CASE OF AL HUSIN v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Expulsion) (Conditional) (Syria);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-c - Reasonably necessary to prevent offence);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-f - Expulsion);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award

TEXT: CARDINAL . It would appear from the case file that the salient fact in the domestic proceedings was the applicant ’s association with the mujahedin in GPE ( “ BH ” ) . The term mujahedin has been widely used to refer to foreigners – mainly from the NORP world – who came to BH during the war in support of NORP . However , the same term has been used to describe local NORP who joined the foreign mujahedin , endorsed their ideology and adjusted to their way of dressing . The phenomenon has been explained by ORG for the former GPE ( “ ORG ” ) in PERSON and PERSON , IT-CARDINAL - CARDINAL-T , § § DATE , DATE , and Delić , IT-CARDINAL - CARDINAL-T , § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL , DATE , as follows .

CARDINAL . The first foreign mujahedin arrived in BH in DATE via GPE and with the assistance of the NORP authorities . It would appear that their arrival was welcomed by the ORG authorities . While the presence of at least some foreign mujahedin seems to have been motivated by a desire to provide humanitarian assistance to the NORP population , most of them actively supported the military struggle against the NORP ORG adversaries , ready to conduct a jihad or “ holy war ” . As stated by PERSON , an ORG witness of NORP origin who came to ORG in DATE , some of the mujahedin were members of ORG who had the aim of “ creating a base that would allow them to increase their area of operations ” . Some of them also came to perform missionary work .

CARDINAL . Upon arrival , foreign mujahedin settled in various locations and did not form a homogeneous entity . Towards DATE , NORP started to join the foreign mujahedin . The locals were provided with military training and participated in combat action . They were also given religious instruction . A number of groups comprising foreign and/or local mujahedin were active . Notwithstanding instances of participation in combat alongside each other , it appears that these groups were anxious to maintain their distinct identities . There were religious and ideological differences between them , which resulted in occasional violent clashes .

CARDINAL . On DATE the foreign mujahedin were organised into a unit within the local ORG ( ORG of GPE ) forces . The unit , named “ GPE ” , was based in GPE . Following its establishment , the unit significantly grew in size . By DATE , it consisted of CARDINAL fighters . Although the original idea had been to replenish the unit with foreign mujahedin only , locals soon outnumbered its foreign members . The factors that motivated locals to join it included : its stricter regimental discipline ; a better degree of organisation ; superior equipment and combat morale ; its religious dedication ; and material benefits . The unit received funds and assistance from many organisations and individuals from the NORP world , including ORG and ORG . ORG in GPE provided logistical support .

CARDINAL . El Mujahedin had a number of features setting it apart from regular ORG units . It was led by foreign mujahedin who were not appointed by the ORG . At the top of the hierarchy was an emir , who has been described as the highest - ranking person within the unit . PERSON , a NORP , was its first emir . In DATE , he was succeeded by an NORP , PERSON , who remained in that position until the end of the war . A different person from the emir , the military commander , headed the military council and was responsible for the conduct of combat operations . In DATE , this post was held by an NORP named PERSON . After his death in DATE , another NORP , PERSON , succeeded him . PERSON was killed in DATE . The unit had a religious council , the shura , which was its supreme decision - making body . It consisted of CARDINAL prominent members of the unit , mostly of NORP origin . The emir was elected by and answerable to the shura . At DATE , Sheikh PERSON joined the leadership of the unit . He was the head of ORG in GPE and known to be an extremist who was well - connected with NORP fundamentalists all over the world ( the ORG relied in that regard on a judgment of ORG of DATE ) . He facilitated the recruitment of volunteers from NORP countries for the struggle in BH . Although Sheikh PERSON did not hold an official function within the unit , its members considered him to be the political authority and even the real emir within the unit . He could issue binding rulings ( fatwa ) and his authority was never challenged by the shura . Sheikh PERSON was killed , together with PERSON , at an HVO ( Croatian Defence Council ) military checkpoint on DATE .

CARDINAL . The General Framework Agreement for Peace , which ended the war in ORG , was initialled at a military base near GPE , GPE , on DATE and signed in GPE , GPE , on DATE . LAW CARDINALA to that Agreement called for the withdrawal of all foreign forces , including individual advisors , freedom fighters , trainers , volunteers , and personnel from neighbouring and other GPE , irrespective of whether they were legally and militarily subordinated to any of the local forces . In view of that , on DATE the ORG disbanded ORG and ordered its foreign members to leave the country by DATE . Despite initial resistance , the shura accepted that the unit be disbanded . It would appear that awards , such as the “ GPE ” , were given to its members as an incentive for foreigners to leave . Members of the unit were also provided with ORG certificates of service , which assisted its foreign members to acquire ORG citizenship . Whereas most of the unit ’s foreign members left ORG , some of them ( such as the present applicant ) applied for ORG citizenship and continue to live in ORG to date .

CARDINAL . After the attacks of DATE , the official attitude towards foreign mujahedin changed dramatically . Many lost their ORG citizenship or were deported from ORG after being declared a threat to national security .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant claimed asylum . The applicant claimed that the NORP authorities were aware of his activities in ORG , as he had always been outspoken about them ( for example , he had given a number of interviews to the ORG television channel and the PERSON newspaper DATE ) . Those authorities had allegedly interviewed his father and brothers on several occasions in this connection and , furthermore , had held one of his brothers in detention for DATE because of his refusal to spy on the applicant . He referred to the situation of PERSON , a mujahedin of NORP origin , who had reportedly been tortured in GPE and sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for membership of ORG ( although no proof of his membership in that organisation had been presented at trial ) , belonging to an organisation formed with the purpose of changing the economic or social structure of the state , carrying out activities that threatened the state or might damage its relationship with a foreign country and weakening national feeling and inciting sectarian strife . The applicant claimed that he might also be targeted because of his draft evasion . Given all the above and the general political and human rights situation in GPE , the applicant argued that his deportation to GPE would expose him to a risk of being subjected to ill - treatment . Lastly , he submitted that his deportation would be contrary to LAW in view of his family situation .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused the asylum claim and granted the applicant a DATE period for voluntary departure . It held that the applicant did not face a real risk of being subjected to ill - treatment given that he had never been a member of ORG ( unlike PERSON mentioned above ) . It further held that it had not been shown that he would be ill - treated solely because of his fighting with the foreign mujahedin in ORG ( in view of the fact that none of the parties to the war in BH were either an ally or an enemy of GPE ) or because of his draft evasion . As regards the applicant ’s allegations about his father and brothers , ORG rejected them as unsubstantiated . Lastly , ORG considered the Article CARDINAL complaint to be irrelevant in an asylum case . On DATE ORG upheld that decision . On DATE ORG set aside the part of ORG decision concerning LAW and remitted it for a retrial . It upheld the remainder of that decision ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

LAW DATE ( Zakon o kretanju i boravku stranaca i azilu , ORG nos . CARDINAL and DATE “ the DATE LAW ) was in force from DATE until DATE . On DATE LAW DATE ( Official Gazette of BH no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL – “ the CARDINAL Act ” ) entered into force . On the other hand , LAW was applied to the applicant ’s detention .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act provided that asylum had to be granted to an alien who , owing to a well - founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race , religion , nationality , political opinion or membership of a particular social group , was outside his or her country of nationality and was unable or , owing to such fear , was unwilling to benefit from the protection of that country . The principle of non - refoulement was incorporated in section CARDINAL of that Act , which read as follows :

“ An alien shall not be returned or expelled in any manner whatsoever to the frontiers of territories where his or her life or freedom would be threatened on account of race , religion , nationality , membership of a particular social group or political opinion , regardless of whether or not the person concerned has been granted asylum . The prohibition of return or expulsion shall also apply to persons in respect of whom there is a reasonable suspicion for believing that they would be in danger of being subjected to torture or other inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment . An alien may not be returned or expelled to a country where he or she is not protected from being sent to such a territory . ”

Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act , aliens whose claims for asylum had been refused had to be granted leave to remain on humanitarian grounds if their removal would breach the principle of non - refoulement .

CARDINAL . NORP Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(i ) of LAW , the authorities were entitled to issue deportation orders against aliens constituting a threat to public order or national security . LAW contains a similar provision ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(h ) of that Act ) . While it is not clear whether an appeal against a deportation order had suspensive effect under LAW ( see section QUANTITY ) , such an appeal suspends deportation under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act . Under both acts , a claim for asylum and an application for judicial review against a refusal of such a claim suspend deportation ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act and sections CARDINAL , CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ) . Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW CARDINAL of LAW , once an alien has become subject to expulsion , removal directions shall be issued within DATE . An appeal does not suspend deportation .

CARDINAL . In accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) of LAW , an alien must be detained if it has been established that he or she constitutes a threat to public order or national security , irrespective of whether a deportation order has been issued . Once a deportation order has been issued , the alien concerned may also be detained under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) of that Act . An initial detention order is valid for DATE ( section CARDINAL ) of that Act ) . It may be extended any number of times for DATE at a time . However , the total period of detention may only exceed DATE in exceptional circumstances , such as if an alien prevents his or her removal or if it is impossible to remove an alien within DATE for other reasons ( see section QUANTITY ) .

CARDINAL . According to many reliable and objective sources , torture and other forms of ill - treatment have been used extensively and with impunity in police stations and security agencies’ detention centres . The relevant part of ORG DATE Country Report on ORG in GPE reads as follows :

“ Under LAW of the constitution , ‘ no one may be tortured physically or mentally or treated in a humiliating manner’ . Nevertheless , security forces reportedly continued to use torture frequently . Local human rights organizations continued to cite numerous credible cases of security forces allegedly abusing and torturing prisoners and detainees and claimed that many instances of abuse went unreported . Individuals who suffered torture or beatings while detained refused to allow their names or details of their cases to be reported for fear of government reprisal .

Former prisoners , detainees , and reputable local human rights groups reported that methods of torture and abuse included electrical shocks ; pulling out fingernails ; burning genitalia ; forcing objects into the rectum ; beatings while the victim is suspended from the ceiling and on the soles of the feet ; alternately dousing victims with freezing water and beating them in extremely cold rooms ; hyperextending the spine ; bending the body into the frame of a wheel and whipping exposed body parts ; using a backward - bending chair to asphyxiate the victim or fracture the spine ; and stripping prisoners naked for public view . In DATE ORG documented CARDINAL types of torture and mistreatment used against detainees in the country . ORG reported that torture was most likely to occur while detainees were held at CARDINAL of the many detention centers operated by the various security services in the country , particularly while authorities attempted to extract a confession or information . Courts systematically used ‘ ORG extracted under duress as evidence , and defendants’ claims of torture were almost never investigated . ”
The relevant part of the most recent concluding observations on GPE of ORG against Torture reads as follows ( document CAT / C / SYR / CO/CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) :

“ The ORG is deeply concerned about numerous , ongoing and consistent allegations concerning the routine use of torture by law enforcement and investigative officials , at their instigation or with their consent , in particular in detention facilities . It is also concerned at credible reports that such acts commonly occur before formal charges are laid , as well as during the pre - trial detention period , when the detainee is deprived of fundamental legal safeguards , in particular access to legal counsel . ”

“ The ORG is also concerned at reports that the ORG has established secret detention facilities under the command of intelligence services , such as the Military Intelligence service , ORG , ORG and ORG . The centres controlled by these services are not accessible by independent monitoring and inspection bodies , and are not subject to review by the authorities . ORG is further concerned that detainees are deprived of fundamental legal safeguards , including an oversight mechanism in regard to their treatment and review procedures in respect to their detention . ORG is also concerned at allegations that those detained in such facilities could be held for prolonged periods without any judicial review , in practice in incommunicado detention and subject to torture or cruel , inhuman or degrading treatment . ”
